news.title: Woman seeks support to fight endometriosis
news.content:
Herald Reporter

A Norton-based woman, Claire Blam Lunga (32), is seeking the support of well-wishers in her fight against endometriosis.

Endometriosis is a condition in which the lining of the uterus grows outside of the uterus.

It then inflames and causes severe pain.

I am unable to take care of my two children because of the extreme pain I am constantly experiencing, said Lunga.

The doctors I have seen here in Zimbabwe have done the best they can for me and are unable to help me further. Thus, my doctor, who is managing my pain, said l should go to India or China for further treatment.

l need to raise US$15 000 for treatment, food, accommodation and air tickets for me and my mother who will take care of me while there.

Please help me to get the chance to work for my children. I am a telecommunications engineer by profession. Help me to be the warrior that I am. Thank you, she said.
news.description: A Norton-based woman, Claire Blam Lunga (32), is seeking the support of well-wishers in her fight against endometriosis.

news.title: Group empowers 160 women
news.content:
Herald Reporter

A local women empowerment lobby group of survivors of gender-based violence has empowered over 160 women by providing resources for mental wellness, career development, and educational opportunities.

The Selfless Sisters Trust, with more than 200 members, primarily consists of survivors of GBV, rape, and those who have attempted suicide.

They aim to empower others by sharing their experiences and demonstrating how to overcome similar challenges.

On Sunday, the organisation hosted an event in Harare where it awarded start-up funding to five young women and offered counselling services to approximately 20 others.

Founding president of Selfless Sisters Trust Ms Irene Sami, who is based in the United States, shared her motivations.

I never want to see any woman go through the same hardships that I endured. The horror I experienced during my childhood compelled me to form this organisation, as I was aware that many others were in need and required assistance.

At just 15, Ms Sami took on the responsibility of caring for her siblings after losing her grandmother. By age 19, she moved to Harare to find work, facing numerous challenges along the way, including an unplanned pregnancy.

I struggled until I was able to educate myself, and eventually, I made my way to the United States, where I now work in a restaurant, she said.

Before her move, Ms Sami had established a car wash and a restaurant operated by survivors of GBV, which led to the founding of the Selfless Sisters Trust in 2021.

Ms Rudo Hariseni, a community leader within the Trust, emphasised the importance of emotional support.

What motivates me is the need to create awareness and provide emotional support for women. Many women are going through trauma, depression, and other challenges that they cannot share with anyone, she said.

A survivor, who chose to remain anonymous, recounted her traumatic experience.

At 19, I was drugged and raped by my boyfriend. I spent six months in the hospital, where doctors worked to remove the drugs from my system. I attempted suicide twice, but I survived.

Now, my dream is to ensure no one else suffers the same trauma, she said.

The event not only provided funding to aspiring entrepreneurs, but also fostered a supportive community. The Selfless Sisters Trust continues to offer counselling and job placement assistance, impacting many womens lives and demonstrating that healing is possible through shared experiences and support.
news.description: A local women empowerment lobby group of survivors of gender-based violence has empowered over 160 women by providing resources for mental wellness, career development, and educational opportunities.

news.title: Joint SADC-EAC Summit opens
news.content:
Zvamaida Murwira

Senior Reporter

A SADC-East African Community virtual joint summit aimed at resolving the conflict in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo is running this evening.

The summit is being co-chaired by SADC chairperson, President Mnangagwa and his EAC counterpart, Kenyan President William Ruto.

The joint summit has gone into closed door deliberations after the co-chairs delivered their opening remarks, giving an overview of the summit.
news.description: A SADC-East African Community virtual joint summit aimed at resolving the conflict in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo is running this evening.

news.title: Industry Minister calls for regional cooperation
news.content:
Online Reporter

INDUSTRY and Commerce Minister Nqobizitha Mangaliso Ndlovu has challenged Sadc Member States to harmonise standards and technical regulations to reduce trade barriers in the region.

Minister Ndlovu said this in a speech read on his behalf by Chief Director Dr Douglas Runyowa at the opening of the 40th Annual Sadc Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT) Cooperation Structures meeting in Victoria Falls today.

The week-long meeting will end on Friday and is being convened under the auspices of the TBT Annex to the Sadc protocol on Trade.

It represents a pivotal moment in the regions collective journey towards regional industrialisation and economic integration.

The meeting is being held under the theme Promoting regional harmonisation of standards for industrialisation and economic growth.

Minister Ndlovu said the meeting is a platform to shape the future of regional trade landscape.

As a region, we have made significant milestones, including the harmonisation of 124 standard texts across diverse sectors. There is also the standardisation of regulations for 21 horticultural fruits and 19 horticultural plants.

This week we will dedicate ourselves to addressing these challenges, focusing on strategic capacity building in metrology, conformity assessment and accreditation to ensure every Member State possesses the requisite tools and resources to fully participate and reap the benefits of our regional frameworks.

We must be committed to finding and harmonising diverse standards ensuring our products meet both regional and international benchmarks, he said.

He said member states strategic frameworks must be aligned with the Sadc Industrialisation Strategy and Roadmap 2015-2063.

He said these efforts are firmly rooted in the regional indicative strategic Development Plan 2020-2030 and the Sadc Vision 2050 guiding our regional integration programmes and actions.

Minister Ndlovu called for collaboration, innovation and unwavering commitment to build a competitive, industrialised regional economy that stands as a beacon of progress and prosperity on the global stage.
news.description: INDUSTRY and Commerce Minister Nqobizitha Mangaliso Ndlovu has challenged Sadc Member States to harmonise standards and technical regulations to reduce trade barriers in the region.

news.title: Zimbabwe commemorates World TB Day
news.content:
Victor Maphosa

Mashonaland East Bureau

Zimbabwe has joined other nations in commemorating World TB Day, with calls for collaboration in the fight against tuberculosis.

The commemorations were held at Mahusekwa District Hospital in Mashonaland East Province under the theme Yes! We can end TB. Commit, Invest , Deliver.

Thousands gathered for the commemorations, with various partners pledging continued support in the fight to end TB.

In his remarks read on his behalf by Provincial Medical Director Dr Paul Matsvimbo, Minister of Health and Child Care Dr Douglas Mombeshora implored everyone to play a part in the fight.

Ending TB in Zimbabwe requires unified effort from all of us. Today l call on every individual, institution, community and organisation to play their part in this fight.

To our programme officers and policy makers, we need your continued commitment to prioritise TB in national health agendas. We should mobilise domestic resources to fill funding gaps.

To our doctors, nurses and environmental health practitioners, your dedication as frontliners in this battle is invaluable.

We need to find every case of TB. Let us continue to innovate to find TB cases and treat them with dignity and compassion, he said.
news.description: Zimbabwe has joined other nations in commemorating World TB Day, with calls for collaboration in the fight against tuberculosis.

news.title: Three ivory dealers run into police trap
news.content:
Thupeyo Muleya

Beitbridge Bureau

Three Beitbridge based ivory dealers were on Friday arrested by the police while looking for buyers for two elephant tusks.

Nokhukanya Gumede (34), Phakamani Maphosa (32) and Josephe Muleya (30) were arrested after being lured by police detectives to a service station where the sale was supposed to be concluded.

Upon their arrest, they were found with 4.1kgs of raw ivory worth US$1472.54.

The trio were not asked to plead when they appeared before Ms Vavariro Gabi on Saturday.

They were remanded in custody to 4 April.

Prosecuting, Mr Tawanda Chigavazira said on March 21, the police got a tip off that the three were selling ivory.

The detectives set up a trap and posed as potential buyers after contacting the accused persons.

They agreed to conclude the deal at a local service station.

Gumede and Maphosa arrived with one of the elephant tusks.

The two were arrested upon arrival and Muleya was also arrested when he arrived with the other tusk.

The raw ivory was confisticated.
news.description: Three Beitbridge based ivory dealers were on Friday arrested by the police while looking for buyers for two elephant tusks.

news.title: Car cleaner steals US$10k from client’s vehicle
news.content:
Prosper Dembedza

Herald Correspondent

A Harare car cleaner has appeared in court on allegations of stealing US$10 000 from a clients car in Mabelreign.

Albert Chimukuyu appeared before magistrate Isheunesu Matova yesterday.

He was remanded in custody.

According to the State, on Saturday at around noon, the unnamed complainant went to a car wash at Mabelreign Shopping Centre.

The complainant left a bag containing US$10 000 and a 9mm Makarov pistol with a magazine of 09 live rounds in his cars glove compartment.

The accused person washed the car and later stole the bag containing the firearm and cash.

He then handed over the car keys to the complainant and fled the scene, the State said.

The court heard that the complainant discovered the offence and filed a police report.

On 23 March, detectives from CID Homicide Harare heard that the accused person was hiding at a lodge in Glaudina, Harare.

Acting on the information, detectives proceeded to the lodge. The accused person was subsequently arrested.

A search was conducted and it led to the recovery of US$1850 and the pistol with a magazine of 09 live rounds, the State said.
news.description: A Harare car cleaner has appeared in court on allegations of stealing US$10 000 from a client's car in Mabelreign.

news.title: Zim gears for digital economy
news.content:
Blessings Chidakwa and Remember Deketeke

The countrys digital landscape has taken a major step forward with the official opening of the IMC Communications Digital Experience Centre in Avondale, Harare.

Information Communication Technology (ICT), Postal and Courier Services Minister Tatenda Mavetera said IMC is set to revolutionize how Zimbabweans interact with mobile and satellite connectivity.

Speaking at the official opening, Minister Mavetera said the state-of-the-art facility is a crucial milestone in the countrys push for digital transformation, aligning with the countrys Vision 2030, which aims to attain an upper-middle-income economy through technological advancements.

This centre is a celebration of how mobile connectivity shapes our future, she said.

It is directly contributing to the Governments goal of establishing Zimbabwes digitally empowered economy.
news.description: The country's digital landscape has taken a major step forward with the official opening of the IMC Communications Digital Experience Centre in Avondale, Harare.

news.title: Court dismisses Madzibaba Ishmael’s application for Constitutional Court referral
news.content:
Prosper Dembedza-Court Correspondent

Apostolic sect leader Madzibaba Ishmaels application for his case to be referred to the Constitutional Court has been dismissed by Norton Magistrate Ms Christina Nyandoro.

The magistrate ruled that the application was frivolous and vexatious, and therefore did not warrant referral.

In his application, Madzibaba Ishmael argued that it was unconstitutional for the court to deny him the opportunity to have his witnesses testify before he presents his defence.

He said his witnesses should be allowed to speak on his behalf while he exercises his right to remain silent.

However, the prosecution, led by Mr Tafara Chirambira and Ms Sheila Mupindu, opposed the application.

They argued that the request was just a delaying tactic with no legal basis.

The State said an accused person must either testify or choose to remain silent, adding that there is no provision allowing witnesses to testify before the accused makes a decision.

Furthermore, they said if Ishmael intends to exercise his right to silence, he should simply declare it, rather than basing it on what might be said by the witness.

Ms Nyandoro ruled that Ishmael had not raised any valid constitutional concerns.

The trial was postponed to April 2 as the defence lawyer was attending a funeral.

Madzibaba Ishmael, also known as Chokurongerwa, is facing three charges  ill-treatment of children, conducting a burial without a burial order, and failing to register the birth and death of a person.

news.title: Government commends Katanga Drop-In Centre for addressing drug abuse
news.content:
Precious Manomano-Herald Reporter

Government has praised the Katanga Drop-In Centre for its critical role in tackling drug and substance abuse.

Established by the Fight Against Substance Abuse and Addictions (FASSA) and the Inspired Angels Network, the centre is strategically located in Katanga, a high-density suburb that is notorious for elevated cases of drug abuse.

During a stakeholders meeting at the centre last Friday, Mashonaland West Minister of State for Provincial Affairs and Devolution Marian Chombo, through a representative, reaffirmed the Governments commitment to supporting the initiative.

She emphasised the importance of collaboration with local authorities, community leaders, and stakeholders to address the root causes of substance abuse.

I commend the centres efforts in providing a comprehensive range of services, Minister Chombo said.

These include assessment and referral services to connect individuals with appropriate treatment programmes, free counselling for vulnerable populations, peer support, and a safe space for individuals to access services without fear of stigma.

These services are essential in addressing drug and substance abuse in our communities.

FASSA director, Dr Abigail Magwenzi described the centre as a safe haven for individuals battling addiction.

We catch them before they become psychotic, Dr Magwenzi explained. This centre acts as a referral point to mental health institutions.

We have engaged over 300 caregivers to ensure a smooth workflow. We have transformed many lives, and the community has become our key stakeholders after witnessing the recovery of drug users.

Since the programmes inception two years ago, over 300 individuals have been successfully rehabilitated at the centre.

Farai, known as Captain Tumbwa, began using substances at the age of 16.

Alcohol was my stimulant. I didnt realize the damage I was doing to myself, he said. I left a good job because of drugs, but now I have completely transformed into a better person.

Several individuals also testified about their relatives transformations, noting their newfound engagement in community projects and church activities.

The Katanga Drop-In Centre continues to be a beacon of hope, minimising drug abuse and fostering recovery within the community.
